This movie has much of the desperate "love me/laugh at me" feel of later era Jerry Lewis films.It's never a good sign when the biggest laugh in the film comes during the outtakes that roll during the credits. It's even worse when that outtake doesn't even have your star in the shot. This movie is not bad enough to be horrible but it's not good enough to be great (or even good for that matter).On a scale of 1 to 10, with 10 being "Austin Powers: International Man Of Mystery" and 1 being "Cat In The Hat", "The Love Guru" gets a 5.

For context I'm a big Austin Powers/Waynes World fan so I *DO* get his humour and I'm not a brainless teen either. I'm a 34 year White male from England who enjoys both 'simple' comedy and more intelligent subtle stuff, if it matters. I've only said this as there is far too much talk of the reasons why people are rating this down but the movie itself is all the evidence you need to see why it's rated low.Sadly I think the funny content from The Love Guru could have been condensed into a 5 minute SNL sketch and worked just as well (OK, would have worked better).I felt the beginning was extremely rushed, the set up was poor and lazy. All the characters were lifeless drones and mostly arbitrary, I didn't know why I should care about anyone.I felt Mike didn't make enough of his character, didn't develop him fully and it was to me a mix of 3 of his previous characters (Fat B******d, Dr Evil and Austin Powers) in one but not as funny or as strong as any of them, certainly not when it's just a single character trying to carry an entire film.It was just weak all round, packed with overused/under-funny puns. There were one or two moments that were genuinely funny or amusing, but by about half way through I just gave up caring and found myself just not laughing anymore.It didn't feel like a Mike Myers movie, it felt like someone had written/directed a movie that they THOUGHT captured the humour of Austin Powers but missed the mark badly. It was a 'by the numbers' attempt at the winning Austin Powers humour that just doesn't work with this set of characters and this plot. A very very thin plot I may add, even for a Mike Myers comedy.On top of that you have the main cast who in my opinion were all miscast except for the main 'hockey player' character who was believable and did a decent job. Perhaps part of the problem though was that Mike Myers should have been playing these central characters himself to fully develop the humour in the film, then again maybe that's just wishful thinking given the terrible pacing and careless direction of the film.I couldn't get a handle on just 'who' Guru Pitka 'was'. He was a mix of all MM's characters but none unique to the new character. It was just very hard to feel anything for GP as his persona seemed to change from scene to scene in the most haphazard/distracting way. A lack of consistency basically.You could never accuse Dr Evil of fluctuating in character throughout a film to the point you give up believing in him or stop caring about his 'funny lines'. Essentially the main character of the Love Guru just isn't strong or compelling enough, maybe he'd be OK as a small character on an Austin Powers movie but he was dreadful as the lead (and only) Mike Myers character on an entire film.Let's just hope they don't make 2 sequels to this terrible waste of talent and potential and with any luck they MAY realise just how special the Austin Powers films were and make some more of those instead of worrying about having to change for the sake of it. Change is good but only if you do better than before, Every single one of the Mike Myers characters that has appeared in an Austin Powers movie could have made a better lead character for a film or spin off than this totally unconvincing 'love guru'.3/10 from me and that's only because of MM of whom I'm a big fan and appreciate for all of his previous, very very funny films.
The Love Guru was the worst movie I have ever seen. The movie was so ridiculous that I wasn't enjoy it at all. This film was a totally disappointing.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as everyone says!
reviews.content: I've always been a fan of Mike Myers, so, for my first review on this site, I thought I'd start off with The Love Guru. This movie has been included among the list of the worst movies ever made. And, while I'll admit it does have it's flaws, I still really like it. And, based on the other reviews, I think I'm the only one who does. I'll start this review off by stating the bad things, and then I'll talk about the good things.Guru Pitka singing 9 to 5 seemed pretty unnecessary, as was his rendition of Space Cowboy. I mean, I get that Pitka's first name is Maurice, but still. Not needed. Some of the jokes were a little immature, too. Half of the penis jokes, short jokes, "I'm making diarrhea sounds with my cup", and stuff like that. Some of the short jokes were funny, but I'll get to that later...Okay, it's later. On to the good things.Stephen Colbert and that other guy who's name escapes me were the highlight of the film. They have the funniest scenes. Justin Timberlake was hilarious as his character, as well. Jessica Alba looked very pretty, like usual and John Oliver was great, too. And, even the most avid of Love Guru haters have to admit that the More Than Words sequence, while generally unneeded, was really pleasant to listen to. Whoever played Raj has a really good voice. Mike Myers also has some really funny scenes, as well. The Pitka vs Rooster scene was one of the funniest, to me.This isn't Myers' best movie by any means, but it isn't his worst either. 7/10

Great comedy, great movie. Most people tell you otherwise but if you don't take it has an insult you'll see the movie is pretty good and funny. Only thing that is not that good is the acting of some actors and some parts of the film seem like they need a little more refinement. Still an awesome movie and one you'll most certainly laugh.

reviews.review_title: One of those films that is as bad as people say.
reviews.content: As once fun as Mike Myers was, now kids today probably won't recognize him and this movie is probably the reason why. Me and my friends loved Austin Powers when we were young and Shrek was almost big as the MCU at the time. This film has absolutely none of the good qualities MM has/had. The humor is so cringy and you can't help but feel like your soul has been violated.I can tolerate gross but not without clever material which this film has none.Trying to satirize Indian and pop culture in a very unfunny way. It's so bad that you're better off watching Seth MacFarlane's lame stoner comedy's (Ted, A Million Ways To Die in the West). Even though I hope Myers gets his career resurrected, it just makes perfect sense that this film killed his career except some minor bits he did here and there. Just avoid for your own good.

The jokes shoot and miss throughout the entire movie. It didn't make me laugh or grin even once and for the 2nd half I was occupied thinking "When is it finally going to be over?".Without the booty here and there and Jessica Alba as eye candy I probably would've even stopped watching it after a while (It's got a lot in common with Uwe Boll's latest disaster "Postal", also is it just me or can you tell which comedy is going to suck by checking if they have "midgets" on the cast just for cheap laughs?).It's too bad really, because with a decent script and a good director it could've been great, maybe not another "Austin Powers" but something similar to "The Guru of Sex" from 2002, which wasn't really all that bad and had some great moments.

It's Funny and Fun!In a new age where EVERYTHING can be offensive. Take it for what it is... Humour!.So many funny moments that I can't define which is funnier... So I say the whole dam thing is enjoyable, witty and smart.Great choice of characters. From bombshell to hunks. From genius to idiot. Then you have the smart plays on words and phrases. And don't forget the guest star cameos.Stupid little person jokes and romantic funnies. Play on a black hockey player having an influence and encouraging young man playing hockey in a basketball court... Funny.I can't stop laughing, and I enjoy revisiting the movie over and over again.SCREW what anybody says... Have fun watching the movie and escape to funny.

I liked it very much. Having read a lot of esoteric stuff, I liked a lot of the ways he humors the new-age spirituality without being arrogant.Here's my small spoiler, as a french-Canadian, I was impressed with Justin's imitation of some french sounds, but the most important one, he didn't get at all (tabarnaque). Directors should understand this better, when using an actor to do another culture, sounds should be perfect or very close to... it kills the magic for us who knows the language (I could have thought he was french, had he said "tabarnak" and not "tabErnak").

reviews.review_title: One of the Funniest Movies I've Ever Seen.
reviews.content: Having been in the self-help and spirituality movements for over 30 years I can say in all honesty that this is one of the funniest movies I've ever seen.Kudo's to Deepak for providing so many clichés. Even more for being the brunt of so many jokes.Myers captures Deepaks voice to the tee.The message is to laugh at yourself while you are 'healing' your wounded inner child and believe you can be successful in spite of all the dysfunction inside and outside of yourself.It is so fast that you'll have to watch it a few times because three jokes have already gone by when you take the time to belly laugh. Mike is truly a comedic genius and a Canadian National Treasure.Allan Hunkin Worthiness.com :)

reviews.review_title: I liked Guru Pitka character very much
reviews.content: Jack Sparrow, Ledger Joker, Guru PitkaThey were serious enough in their goals, but also they never took a path with the same seriousness. It is a very clear message, because Life is Hard. They all like to do tough jokes, even in difficult moments. This may look like foolishness, but maybe these characters realized that work is best done if people can refocus their concerns. If you recall, instead of receiving the best answer to an specific problem, they bring a very funny alternative that can make us free our worries. Was Guru Pitka's morbidity level high? Those were jokes! "but it's cool for Tom Green to hump a dead moose" as Eminem said.

I don't understand why this has gotten such a bad rap! It's a classic light hearted Mike Myers film, with an easy to follow plot line that just makes me laugh. I especially like the 'Mariska Hargitay' joke, which is absolutely hilarious if you're a Law and Order fan like myself. There are a few very over the top films, but criticizing Mike Myers for being eccentric is like criticizing Quentin Tarantino for being overly dramatic. Though there are similarities between this film and the 'Austin Powers' series, there is enough individuality to create an overall well made film. Please watch this movie for yourself, don't base your opinion on it's poor reviews.

I rarely write reviews but I saw this movie when it had first came out. I recently rewatched it with some buddies of mine once it dropped on Netflix. They had never seen it and they all love Mike Myers so i tossed it's on. Afterwards i told them how poorly received this movie was and they all agreed that it was genuinely a funny film. It's truly a shame it got barraged with such negative reviews but it's good to see that some people on here agree with my friends and i on this one. It's not Austin Powers level funny but it does the trick. Just sit back, relax and enjoy some stupid comedy. Sidenote: I'd really put this at a 8/10 but to snuff out the haters i put a 10/10. it's nothing groundbreaking but it's all good fun!

Hello,If you like tongue in cheek humor, movies like The Naked Gun, Blazing Saddles and endless other classics, please try this movie.The 3.8 rating is a total disgrace.I rated this movie a 7 but changed it now to a 10 to compensate for the clowns leaving low reviews.Mike Myers is a great human.RIP Vern Troyer.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as everyone says... not great either...
reviews.content: I am a huge Austin Powers fan.. loved all the movies...I really had high hopes for this, but i was disappointed.. a little bit..the movie had some hilarious moments.. but also some awful ones.. and you are probably gonna be bored throughout 35-40% of the film..the really funny moments does weigh it up a bit though...it is certainly better than all those horrible comedies ending in "-movie" - like Date Movie, Epic Movie etc. etc.it is nowhere near as bad as the IMDb score says.. but it's not a masterpiece either...6/10

I loved this movie! I laughed the entire time. If you are am Austin Powers fan you will love the guru. It was similar in that the jokes were sexually charged but bedroom humor is always fun to watch as a couple. Teenagers will probably get the same amount of humor, enough to enjoy the feature. Although I have read some bad reviews, I think that they were probably a little squeamish to the type of humor, or in general needed to vent some steam and they just used the Guru as a target. Go get laid or find Jesus people! I recommend this movie to anyone looking for a good date night movie, or as a movie to enjoy between the guys or girls. I am not endorsing sexual behavior in underage kids, but I do think it is something teenagers would enjoy as a slumber party movie or something. There is not actual nudity shown, although implied, and there are no sex scenes to speak of...well...there was that one time with the circus elephants... Enjoy the show!

reviews.review_title: WHY do people hate this movie so much!
reviews.content: So bizarre to me.I mean, it's silly sure but I much preferred it to the third Austin Powers movie. The second one is my favourite comedy film of all time though :)I'd say it's like 60-70% as good as Austin Powers 1.Similar style of comedy and similar character.Just a good fun little film. It's silly for sure but is that necessarily bad?So yeah I don't get it at all. I feel like sometimes people just pick something to hate on and that's that!

reviews.review_title: How bad must the deleted scenes be?
reviews.content: I haven't written a comment in years, but felt compelled to warn movie goers about this one. If you're expecting a comedy let me tell you I didn't laugh once. Waynes World 1 & 2, Austen Powers 1-3 go into the Hall of Fame of comedies in my opinion, but this is as bad as those movies are good. It could be a blip, but I think it's going to be very difficult for Myers to get his career back on track after this. My rating was 5 when I started writing this review, but it gradually went down to 3 the more I thought about it. It really is annoying me more as time passes. Bringing in the new King of Pop, the best looking woman in the world and the small guy again did nothing to paper over the large cracks.

reviews.review_title: Don't Be To Hard On it.....
reviews.content: I have seen some terrible movies in my time......This is not one of them!!! Mike Mires is a genius he writes, acts, directs and gets his celebrity friends to join in the fun!!!One thing i especially liked was the fact nobody was afraid to have fun!! everybody who appeared on film enjoyed themselves!!! Okay there was no deep plot or huge drama, but there is not supposed to be!! its a witty smart comedy that is incredibly light hearted in a world that is so serious. Mike Mires says if i can take the laugh at myself i can throw caution to the wind and just be funny!! Just take the movie for what it is and let the humor take over.

reviews.review_title: So glad i didn't leave during the start!
reviews.content: I feel that this movie is getting a lot of unfair reviews simply because people cant wait to copy the critics opinion. God, you all remind me of Sean Penn. By the way, if the Austin Powers series never was released, all of you would love this! The movie however did start badly. I had read some bad reviews beforehand but I wanted to go and enjoy this. What I think was wrong with the start was the pure unfunnyness of it. Mike was acting horribly and the 9 to 5 song made feel like I was Julian in The Happening.Around the time he met Mariska Hargitay the movie improved. What I admired about it was the spontaneous and outrageous humor and the cock double entendres. Although I do see why people could hate this.JESSICA ALBA WAS MISCAST. She was acting like a block of wood and the character she was portraying should have been much older and she didn't look the part.3 words can sum this film up. Average Myers Comedy.

reviews.review_title: Movie was not that great.... but Alba makes it worthwhile
reviews.content: I went to the red carpet Hollywood premiere of this movie. Good thing the tickets were free cause I would have never paid 11 dollars to see this movie! I am a fan of the Austin Powers series (except for the goldmember)and this to me was pretty much like an Austin Powers 4 (similar jokes and gags). Funnier than the third, not as good as the second.The whole premise of this movie was retarded to begin with (not going to go too much into the plot). It started out kind of awkwardly and a lot of the scene transitions did not flow smoothly. Most of the movie was based on physical comedy with a couple of humorous jokes. There was a lot of toilet humor and penis jokes as well. I laughed maybe 5-6 times throughout the whole movie. The whole acronym thing gets old very fast. The theater did laugh more than I did but I think it was just to be polite to Mike Meyers/Justin Timberlake and the writers/producers/director of the film who were in the audience.The one thing I very much enjoyed about this movie was the ABSOLUTELY GORGEOUS Jessica Alba. She looked EXTREMELY hot in this movie, hotter than anything she has ever been in. I was just mesmerized watching her, especially when she was wearing the Indian saris (dresses) and doing the dances. Oh my. Cash Warren has to be the luckiest man in the world.5/10
If you could edit out Mike Myers from the movie, I bet the movie would be 100x better.

This movie is one of my favorite movies growing up. I would keep the DVD on repeat and just die with laughter, the jokes never got old to me and now that I'm older I actually understand them. It's nothing deep but definitely a nice movie to laugh at

Loved it!!! One of the best movie I have ever seen. Comedy!!! I loved it! If I could rate my favorite movies in order it would be easy~ but I have seen a lot of movies so it got into my favorite 5! It automatically drew my attention with hysterical laughter! It drew my attention the first second it started! I liked it a lot! It drew my attention! I loved it. I could watch it a million times and never forget the feeling I had when I first watched it! it is a great movie! I can't believe some people don't like it :(! It's amazing to me how much fun it is to watch! ~~~~~~ I have fun even watching it. I would do: Dirty Dancing, Ghost, Hotel for Dogs, then The Love Guru

reviews.review_title: The funniest moment was a blooper in the credits...

The movie is just full of jokes that belongs in a movie for 3-year-olds...i laughed for real once in the whole movie...that was when they where showing a behind-the-scenes clip in the credits where the midget was standing in front of many people with their backs turned against the camera and you could see the midget and many asses ^^ the director says: "Can we move the camera? all i can see is asses" and then the midget says: "now you know how it feels" and the crew starts laughing and so did i.....so...did...i.....so for future generations ^^ buy this movie to skip to the credits to watch this epic clip and you've got your money worth :) But trust me...even twilight is better than this sh*t.-smestad1

reviews.review_title: Well, it does have Daily Show alumni in it
reviews.content: It's an unfunny movie, what looks like another bad SNL sketch stretched into a paper thin mess. I personally never thought Mike Myers was funny, and this movie really shows it. He looks like he's uncomfortable doing his own stupid lines and jokes, as does everyone else in the film. There's a lot of dead air in the movie as well, just a lot of quiet with not much happening but silly dialogue. The penis jokes got old fast, almost as if Mike Myers has a fetish. The including of Verne Troyer was a novelty that just didn't work. In fact most things in this movie just didn't work. The couple highlights: It was nice seeing current and former Daily Show players on here (Stephen Colbert, John Oliver, and even Samantha Bee for a second), too bad none of them were given anything funny to say. The scene with Mike Myers and Kanye West together at the game was an interesting idea, but was obviously tacked on, they didn't even say anything. And um, Jessica Alba is still hot. That's about it.
Seen a few reviews and you can have off course your own opinion. But I really like these kind of movies. It is not as bad as the imdb critics tell. A big loving positive 8.

But it's the best. I think they made a movie with an algorithm. I v e never hated anything more... but I would kill anyone who dare oppose it. It's just the internet randomized...I just want everyone to explain themselves. Why... would you just... go along with this charade. I love so many people in this movie and now I want them all to answer for their crimes.

reviews.review_title: One of the worst movie I saw for years
reviews.content: First let me tell that if I rate this movie 2 and not 1, that's just because it features Jessica Alba (regarding of who I must admit that I'm very partial). This said, let's talk about the movie itself.First, the humor: its a showoff of stupid vulgarity, a literal insult to the viewer intelligence. I know that Myers movie are not reputed for their subtle jokes and sense of good taste, but this one is the worst of all. Then, the story : if I say that its annoying story, that nothing really happens, and the viewer never surprised, I would still be far from the infamous truth. The acting is quite bad too, the characters have no personality, and Myers omnipresence, surely the fact of his gigantic ego, doesn't help the viewer to have a better experience.As a conclusion: run, fast!

I saw this movie, and not under test screening, something like that, but in the theaters. It's true that he is using some of his old tricks on girls, in The Love Guru, but this movie is refreshingly sensational.For me, it's hard to laugh at a movie, that has it's own good humor, but this one made me, especially when Sir Ben Kingsley appeared, whit his sick eyes.
Re-watching this in 2020 due to corvid lockdown,and its my 5th time total sill made me laugh.A good movie but not for everyone i guess.

Mike Meyers makes his return to live-action comedy with this winking farce on America's spirituality fad. It would be more fun to watch if it wasn't so sloppily put together. It's a vehicle for Meyers, who does this sort of broad, over-the-top character as good as any of his SNL buddies. But he gets too indulgent here, stringing along a funny premise on a paper-thin plot with endless penis, midget, poop, and sex jokes. The director's inability to make the gags stick doesn't help. There is some satire here but not enough. Meyers scores laughs on and off. You know there's a problem when Justin Timberlake (hilarious in a wig, moustache, and silly accent) is the funniest thing in your movie. Romany Malco is wasted, Jessica Alba and Meagan Good are merely eye candy, some cameos score, and Stephen Colbert is almost as funny as he is on his show. Some laughs, a few nice song and dance numbers, and the outrageous Timberlake make this almost watchable, but Meyers all but kills the potential this had with his comedic self-indulgence. Disappointing
Don't waste your time on this except when drunk or stoned.

One of the funniest movies out there, a Mike Myers classic. Some may say racist but give me a break. It's comedy, if you take it serious get outta here and just enjoy it.
Horrible movie and plot.

The Love Guru is not only the worst movie of Michael Myers' career, this is easily one of the worst comedies ever made.  It's shallow, it's crude, it's full of gross-out humor, and is one of the very few times I can actually say I was almost outright offended by it.  The main character is not remotely likable, the plot completely idiotic and nonsensical, and 90 minutes of continuous farts would actually be an improvement from an intellectual standpoint.

It was solid. A big step back from Mike Myers peak in Austin Powers. I still enjoyed it and had some laughs. Full of stupid puns and word salad jokes. I remember seeing the ads for this and it just looking horrendous so I never watched till recently.
I love Mike Myers unfortunately this movie was so far out there this must have been financed by Him.  Plus it was stupid and ignorant scenes.

Overall, the plot of this film is good, it wraps up nicely, and there are many gags that land. I'd say out of all the Meyers' films, this is one of the best written, but, it fails the parody in places. While it's obvious the makers had their ear to Hinduism and Buddhism, it's not as booby-trapped with those myths like a Mel Brooks or Monty Python spiritual comedy. Maybe they consulted eastern philosophers while making this, but, you can tell they didn't grow up in it like Kevin Smith did in his Catholic Dogma, because this film could be a lot more than it was.

Jessica Alba is horrible in this, like she can barely contain the hatred for her own part while she smiles like Vaseline has been rubbed all over her teeth. She is a very successful business woman, and it is clear from this film that's the lane should drive in. 

Justin Timberlake can hang with super-jokers like Meyers, and he does a good enough job, but, he's like Wonderbread; the name makes you want to eat it, but, you realize it isn't particularly nutritious and is only created for its shelf life. 

Hindu and Buddhist myths are so wonderful, many times you can be creating something and turn to the myths and find it has already been created, and then you can toy with the two creations meeting again. I don't think that was done here, and they missed out by not studying their subjects more before filming.
Don't judge me. Guilty pleasure for sure.
Worth watching. Kinda weird but it has lots of laughs.

One of the funniest movies EVER! People that gave this movie a bad review are sad, and lonely individuals. ! Jessica Alba and Justin Timberlake are pretty good and Meyers is his usual amazing self. It's very much like even he knows how far apart in quality the movies are yet is still willing to try and coax you into a cesspool of toilet gags/rancid "puns"/borderline offensive ethnic stereotypes and a feeling you are being fleeced with every passing second you remain seated in watching this dross.

From the 90's up until the 2000's, Mike Myers has become a giant name in comedy, landing in successes like the Wayne's World, Austin Powers and Shrek franchises. But soon after, people got tired of his shtick really fast after seeing the ultimate sunken ship of his career, The Love Guru. This story about Maurice Pitka (Mike Myers), the Hollywood sex guru one star below Deepak Chopra, who's tasked to retie a knot between Maple Leaf player Darren Roanoke (Romany Malco) and his wife Prudence (Meagan Good) in order to win the Stanley Cup, became a box office and critical flop in 2008. Seeing this movie today, it's hard not to miss why. Unlike Myers's previous characters, Maurice doesn't have much of a personality, aside from a bad Indian stereotype who spouts out preschool-level bathroom humor and even worse sexual double entendres. As for the supporting cast, Jessica Alba looks like she's waiting in line for the catering table as the Leafs manager and cookie-cutter love interest Jane. Academy Award winner Ben Kingsley is watching his career slowly wilting as the cross-eyed elder guru Tugginmypudha. Verne Troyer is once again type-casted as the punchline for jokes about… you know what, as well as Coach Cherkov. The movie also features an odd line of celebrity cameos from Val Kilmer, Mariska Hargitay, and Kanye West, who are all identified by name, which ruins the joke of a cameo. As far as career-ruining pictures as concerned, The Love Guru is one unfunny dead zone. (1 ½ D.R.A.M.A.TM Tattoos out of 5)

The Austin Powers' Trilogy really shot up Mike Myers' comedy career, and this is a testament to that. I am a movie collector that has seen A LOT of comedy movies, them being my specialty of course. Although this movie is lowballed by many film critics, this is actually my FAVOURITE movie of ALL time! This movie is comedy gold on the cast's behalf. The characters throughout the movie have well-placed side plots that all add up in the end. An awesome script that seems like natural comedy creates a flowing script, an example including the alligator soup being snappy joke. I understand that to some people this might not be funny, but in order to get the most out of the movie, you have to look at it the way it was intended to be looked at. Although all of this is my opinion, the movie is truly hilarious in many ways. But you can decide for yourself.

My initial reaction after watching this was very telling. I wondered if the editors, while working long and hard nights, saw the shot footage and knew it was unsalvageable mess. To imagine that every scene in the final cut was the best possible outcome is painful. I can only imagine how nauseous the on-set experience must have been.

I love Mike Meyers. And he really does try his best on this one. But I keep feeling like there's something inherently unfunny about an Indian guru. Not quite sure why, but despite his best attempts this just didn't work. And apparently all great comedic actors are incapable of discerning whether a script is good or bad, and accept all movie offers that come their way. Will Ferrell, Eddie Murphy, Mike Meyers... They all do great stuff as well as total bombs. This movie was unwatchable, unfunny, and an embarrassment for all involved. Just a bunch of silly gags that fall flat. But Jessica Alba is, as always, hot. I suggest you watch Austin Powers or Wayne's World instead.

Mike Meyers continues his obsession with racial stereotypes, midgets, and name puns in 2008's The Love Guru. To be fair, there is an extremely subtle Wayne's World reference in a scene that made me laugh, but that was the only time I did so much as chuckle during the entire movie. Blink and you might miss it, too. I hate this movie so very much. I liked Austin Powers. I liked Shrek. Mike Meyers' sense of humor can work. But this is inexcusable. There is not a single character who has so much as an actual personality. Mike Meyer's character is just a stupid accent who has an infinite supply of fart jokes. Justin Timberlake barely says anything, Jessica Alba doesn't even react to the wildly bizarre things Meyers says, and poor Ben Kingsley must have been in a contract with Paramount to have the 15 minutes of screen time he has. There are a lot of pointless cameos, a lot of racially insensitive themes, and a lot of gratuitous sequences. Like there's this one part, totally out of nowhere, where Mike Meyers, for no reason, forces two elephants to hump. For absolutely no reason. I guess this might have worked if it was just in the middle of the movie, but no, this acts as a climax for this atrocity. It is the most important part of the movie. Everything in acts 1 and 2 was building up to this, and everything in act 3 builds off of this. It's never explained but for whatever reason, we're supposed to believe that what we just witnessed is a major element of the movie. Not to mention the terrible CG'd child scenes, the recycled gags, and it's ruthless murdering of Mike Myers' career. Besides it being pointless, it's mean-spirited, racist, and the worst movie I've seen in years.

It is strange to understand what certain individuals think is noble by deciding to hate this movie for a personal prejudice. People that usually do not write reviews went out of their way to ensure that this film would not do well at the box office. Barack Obama among those that felt they needed to tell the world not to see this movie. That being said, I think it is fascinating to speculate about what about the movie they felt so offensive. Is it really with the type of humor? I mean after all this film is on par with the grossness levels of his other films, but nobody seemed to have a problem with them. Is it with the way that Mike Myers portrays the Hinduism? Although the Hindu American Foundation did report that the movie was crude and vulgar (which is kind of like stating the obvious right?), they did not report the movie was anti-Hindu. And how could it be. Mike Myers apparently went through a very serious depression after his father died. He talked about it in a very strange interview with Terry Gross on Fresh Air. Mike Myers apparently was deeply helped by Hindu influenced spirituality. The movie is overwhelmingly positive in regard to Hindu influenced spirituality that he himself benefited from. This I believe to be what individuals like Barack Obama had a problem with in the Love Guru. The movie had some funny moments, but I think it is noble of Mike Myers to try to provide a positive message for a change. It is awful that individuals would discourage positive messages in comedies.

It hardly mattered that a lot of Americans were clueless as to what Mike Myers was satirizing when the titular character from "Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery" became something of a comic zeitgeist in the late-nineties and early It hardly mattered that a lot of Americans were clueless as to what Mike Myers was satirizing when the titular character from "Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery" became something of a comic zeitgeist in the late-nineties and early 21st century. That voice alone, an instrument in which Myers played all the right mercurical and randy notes, transcended the typical American moviegoer's limited grasp of film history. Myers brought swinging London across the Atlantic, and for a brief period, he was the only comic actor that mattered. But subsequent sequels, were less funny, less swinging, as Myers' penchance for gross-out humor started to grow tiresome. Fat Bastard was his nadir. The trend continues here. Jokes about masturbation, flatulence, male genitalia, urine, and "midgets" inspires silence, not laughter. And worst of all, the voice isn't funny. The Guru Pitka sounds like a child molester. And hockey? A comedy about hockey and Deepak Chopra? Myers, whose last notable appearance was playing straight-man to Kanye West as the rapper told a post-Katrina audience on live television that George W. Bush didn't like black people, gets his revenge for playing the unwilling stooge. In "The Love Guru", there's the temptation to look at Darren Roanoke(Romany Malco), a black hockey player for the Toronto Maple Leafs, as a stand-in for West. For the record, Roanoke has a smaller penis than Jacques Grande(Justin Timberlake), and is scared of his mother. Think about it. What could be more emasculating to a rap artist? And finally, "The Love Guru" makes reference not just once(Coach Punch Cherkov's office is just like the seven-and-a-half floor in Charlie Kaufman's Martin Flemmer building), but twice, to Spike Jonze's "Being John Malkovich". The Los Angeles Times headline that proclaims Deepak Chopra's dominance over the Guru Pitka is an obscure reference to the John Cusack character bitching about living in the shadow of Derek Mantini(Ned Bellamy), who Craig Schwartz(Cusack) watches from his couch, as the populist puppeteer mounts a giant Emily Dickinson presentation("The Belle of Amherst") on live television. The Jonze film establishes a skewered world where puppeteers matter, as does "The Love Guru", which overstates the importance of spiritualists like Deepak Chopra in the popular culture. That's the only cerebral component in this puerile, mean-spirited, and above all else, cynical, film, that's purported to be a comedy, but is more like an object of performance art that deconstructs comedy and the human heart.

It's hard to pinpoint exactly when it was that Mike Myers went over to the dark side, but it happened long before The Cat in the Hat. Most likely it occurred during the first 10 minutes of Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me, when It's hard to pinpoint exactly when it was that Mike Myers went over to the dark side, but it happened long before The Cat in the Hat. Most likely it occurred during the first 10 minutes of Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me, when Myers, wanting to make his shagadelic superspy a free agent again, betrays Elizabeth Hurley, the surprisingly believable (and endearing) romantic interest from the original AP: International Man of Mystery, as well as all sense of continuity and logic by writing Hurley out of the series permanently, in just about the laziest and most perfunctory way possible. (Uh, what evidence was there in the original that Mimi Rogers gave birth to a fembot?) This marked the complete sacrifice of the sweetness and heart in Myers' movies in favor of increasingly gross and juvenile gags replete with Myers replacing wit with elaborate makeup stunts that don't exactly cause Rick Baker too many sleepless nights. In short, while Man of Mystery was filled with Myers' affection for James Bond, Matt Helm, Derek Flint, Burt Bachrach and 1960s British pop culture, the two sequels feature Myers' affection for nobody and nothing save Myers. Austin Powers is gone, baby, gone, but Myers' self-indulgent egomania lives on in the relentlessly puerile and painful The Love Guru, the least of whose sins is Myers' refusal to make his central character (an Indian spiritual teacher who contradicts his philosophies by being obsessed with materialism and one-upping Deepak Chopra) an object of even the most obvious satire; such is Myers' preening desire to have the audience love him, which results in one of the most preening, obnoxiously camera-hogging performances in recent movie history. ("Couldn't you just eat me up?" Myers asks. "Yes, and then puke you right back out," we reply.) The jokes themselves are so endlessly, assaultively crass and prepubescent (which can be forgivable, if they're funny) that even Myers' fellow Canadians Terrence and Philip would launch a protest campaign. Marco Schnabel's direction is so amateurish that viewers really come to appreciate Jay Roach's expert staging of even the flimsiest material in the Powers trilogy. Concerning the performances, when JESSICA ALBA comes across the best in a movie, you know it's in trouble; she's no actress by anybody's standards (except maybe her immediate family's) but as the unlucky owner of a hockey team whose star player is counseled by the hero, Alba is certainly pleasant, natural, and has an extremely winning smile--fortunately, due to Schnabel's ping-pong camera placement in her scenes with Myers, you at least get to see it exactly 50% of the time! Alba's costars don't come across quite so well, to say the least; as Myers' cross-eyed mentor, Sir Ben Kingsley (The Wackness) not only puts Sir Laurence Olivier's late career Polaroid commercials and The Jazz Singer in their proper perspective, but proves that it's possible to sink lower in one's career than working for director Uwe Boll. Stephen Colbert, playing a drug-addled sportscaster, cause moviegoers to seriously question the intelligence, slyness and wit he regularly brings to Comedy Central's The Colbert Report. Fortunately for Colbert, however, The Love Guru deservedly had very few moviegoers in attendance, so Colbert's reputation remains intact!

rt_summary: Born in America and raised in an Indian ashram, Pitka (Mike Myers) returns to his native land to seek his fortune as a spiritualist and self-help expert. His skills are put to the test when he must get a brokenhearted hockey player's marriage back on track in time for the man to help his team win the Stanley Cup.
